This IRM provides guidelines and procedures for the computer audit specialist (CAS) to follow when conducting an examination involving a statistical sample.
The changes in this IRM revision are limited to:

Renamed IRM 4.47.3.1, Program Scope and Objectives, in accordance with the internal control requirements described in IRM 1.11.2, Internal Management Documents System, Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) Process.

) The objective of the statistical sampling auditing technique is to maximize effective use of statistical sampling in IRS examinations, and at the same • Ensure that estimates of adjustments to tax liabilities resulting from tistical samples are statistically sound and legally defensible. • Ensure the fair and equitable treatment of taxpayers examined by statistical sampling techniques. (

) To attain this objective, the DFO will: • Explore and identify areas where statistical sampling may be used to improve the quality and effectiveness of examinations, investigations, and compliance projects. • Identify and develop the tools necessary for implementing statistical sampling in examinations. • Provide training recommendations and assist in the development of training for examiners at all levels. • Coordinate and monitor the use of statistical sampling by providing mechanisms for distributing technical information and providing assistance. ) Requests for CAS assistance will be made through the LB&I Specialist Referral System (SRS). (
) CASs can request assistance from a SSC by initiating a consultation using SRS. Non-CAS employees should ﬁrst work with a local CAS before questing a SSC. (
) The request for SSCs must be sent to the statistical sampling team responsible for the SSCs. (
) Projections obtained from examination of statistical (probability) samples of counting records may be used as the basis for proposing adjustments to reported on a tax return. (

) Statistical sampling should be considered whenever a group of accounting entries or transactions has sufficient adjustment potential to warrant tion, but the examination of all such transactions is prohibitive in terms of and resources. In any audit situation where it is reasonable to examine
percent of the items under consideration, statistical sampling techniques should not be used. (

) The precision of any statistical sample, to some degree, is based on the sample size used. With estimation sampling plans, optimum sample sizes be determined from a preliminary sample. Where feasible and within the ex- amination constraints, preliminary samples may be used to estimate a supplemental sample size which when added to the original results will the desired degree of precision required by the plan. (
) The CAS manager or an SSC needs to review and approve IRS statistical samplings. (

) An SCC referral is required when: a. An IRS sample is designed with a projectable stratum with less than items. b. Reviewing and evaluating taxpayer statistical samples. c. Developing a Return Preparer penalty statistical sample. (

(or more version) will be used by all CASs upon completion of their training on the of the program. This application may be updated from time to time with technical corrections and enhancements. Updates of the program will be tributed to authorized users of the application by Information Technology. SSC manager will be responsible for maintaining program documentation. (
) This application will be used on all IRS initiated statistical samples and to the validity of all taxpayer proposed statistical samples. (
) If a taxpayer or their representatives request this application, the requestor should be advised to use the Freedom of Information Act process. (
) All questions or requests for additional information regarding the application should be directed to a SSC.

This exception occurs when the IRS performs a statistical sample to put the taxpayer into compliance. Sampling units should be selected for the sample based on random number selection techniques. Any unusually large transactions may be grouped into a separate stratum examined in their entirety. In stratiﬁed sampling situations, a stratum could be deleted or added to the population without affecting the validity of the sample; however, there should be sound reasons for doing so. ) In analyzing individual entries generated by a transaction, the examiner must deal with two types of problems: determining the validity of an entry, and mining the associated adjustments to other accounts when errors are encountered. These problems must be properly dealt with in any audit; however, if sampling techniques are being used, special care must be taken. (
